author: ddlezu01
title: CLAP for impactful research
description: Social enterprise related projects tend to struggle when it comes to raising funding for important issues and this can affect their well-being as well as subsequent motivation to continue.

f6_assessments.q0:
From the announcements made by IOG and Cardashift, there was no indication of any further future challenges in collaboration, meaning that this might be a one-time event. The previous Catalyst Natives challenge was also a one-time event. As such, the scope of this proposal, to apply the findings and experience of the funded proposers from this funding round to a future one, geared towards Africa could prove to be, unfortunately, to no avail.
Maybe the team should have consulted before writing this proposal, to make sure that the work they will be putting into writing this proposal would not be in vain, and could have used the opportunity to write perhaps another one.
For this reason, I find it hard to agree with the impact of this proposal, since I’m not sure that it could be implemented, especially since the Cardashift team has clearly mentioned in the brief that they will “in its discretion, determine the suitability of the project proposals selected by the Catalyst community and carry out any checks or diligence before engaging with such project teams”.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposers have identified 4 steps for the implementation of their project, each detailed with a description of needed actions. What I’m unclear at this part of the proposal, is whether the number of months in the parentheses details the number of months needed to complete those certain actions or if it is the corresponding month on the timeline when that certain step will take place. Regardless of this detail, the team goes on to describe each step of the project with a summary for each. The budget is split into 5 categories, and each category has a bullet list of actions for which the amount is allocated for. What would have been helpful in assessing the budget and timeline would have been the addition of a number of hours needed for each action and a corresponding rate per hour. Without these data, it’s hard for me to gauge the feasibility of the budget, in terms of finance as well as in terms of time allocated.
Regarding the team members, there is some detail offered for each of them, with corresponding LinkedIn links and previous Catalyst experience, as such although I would have liked to see similar amounts of information for each of the team members, I do not see a problem in not having it and consider the team as being capable to implement the proposal.
The team has answered as having another proposal in this fund and from previous funds, yet, although specified in the proposal submission, they haven’t provided any details, like titles, links, descriptions or descriptions on how the team will manage their time in relation to all proposals or if any of the proposals are inter-related with information benefitting one another.
Given the information provided, I find that the missing details keep me from agreeing or disagreeing that the proposal can be successfully implemented, as such, I will rate it with a score of 3.
f6_assessments.q2:
I find that for the purpose of this proposal, there could have been additional metrics provided in order for the community to verify the progress of the project. For instance, metrics related to the database they are planning to build, or the number of questions answered by the funded proposers. The process described by them in the detailed plan section had a great focus on the first steps of implementation, namely, database creation, survey writing or research,  yet here in the auditability section, they are being overlooked entirely.
The answer provided for the vision of success offers a glimpse into how the team sees their project and values it. As such, I find this answer to be reasonable.
In conclusion, while the answer to the success question is well written,  I find the progress metrics to be incomplete, according to the information provided in the other sections of the proposal.
Given this, I can only rate it a 3.

f6_assessments.q0: The problem is that social entrepreneurship enterprises frequently fail to secure money for pressing needs, which has an impact on both their drive to carry on and their overall wellbeing. By doing research to learn what works with those who have already submitted CLAP ideas and what can be improved to attract more submissions, the proposal seeks to address this issue and then apply what is learned to African proposers. These would enable more social entrepreneurship ventures to receive funding, address pressing challenges, and benefit the ecosystem. The proposal successfully resolves the issue.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal should be successfully executed because the proposer has experience in both research and catalysts. The proposal does include a well-defined plan for implementation, and it also accounts for the resources required. The $30000 budget does seem a bit excessive. The project has been broken down into phases, and the proposer has considered all potential risks and offered ways to mitigate them. These increase the likelihood that this proposal will be effectively implemented.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal's progress can be tracked because the proposer has specified specific tasks, each with a timeline. Additionally, they included a budget breakdown that will be helpful for auditing. The provided key performance indicators and Sustainable Development Goals can be used to evaluate how well the proposal is working. The proposer has also described how it will benefit the community and what success will look like. All of this information ought to be sufficient to evaluate the proposal's development and effectiveness.

f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer and team have experience in Front End web development, cloud computing, cybersecurity, decentralized applications, PA at Fund 7, etc... These experiences will greatly benefit the team in implementing Cardano-related proposals. The team has also provided full documents related to the proposal (websites, videos,...). Especially the Linked social network link, has the effect of publicizing the identity of team members. I am impressed with this because the detailed listing of members and publicity through social networks does not work for all proposals. I applaud the team for making this clear and very specific. The disclosure of identity through Linkedin facilitates the community to look up the members' identities and verify the feasibility of the proposal. The number of members in the group is 2 people, I understand these are the key members, the team may also have other members or collaborators who are not convenient to identify.
The budget is divided by items and sticking to the goal. The team simply lists the budget and shows the key milestones, However, as a PA, I still want the team to show even more clear details about the budget required for each small job so that the community can look at it and be more confident about the feasibility of the proposal. It's perfectly understandable for the team to present the budget as it is to people who already know the team well, but I suppose for everyone from the community (some people are very new - they don't know yet). know nothing about the team and don't know anything about this proposal) can understand it easily, we need a more detailed, more understandable presentation. That's my advice on budget presentation. I have an additional question, if it hasn't been funded by Catalyst in Fund 9, will the team continue to work on this proposal? What other sources of funding does the team have to be able to implement this proposal (including funding that comes from contacting support from other organizations)? I ask this question because I want to demonstrate the clear feasibility of the budget.
The plan and how to do it has been stated with a process of 4 big steps to do the work (I will call it 4 big steps). Each big step will be a small task - the team has shown professionalism in planning implementation. This is also one of the important factors in clearly defining the feasibility of the proposal. And the team is doing a great job of it.
Regarding the necessary resources for implementation, I temporarily divided them into two main resources: financial resources (mentioned in the above budget) and human resources. With the current people and good expertise, the proposal can be successfully implemented. However, the proposal presented is that some members are also working on another proposal in parallel with this proposal at Fund 9. I would like to ask if this will reduce the quality of work on this proposal. ? Because human resources are scattered when implementing different proposals. I understand maybe the team has other members/collaborators to work together. However, I think the team should demonstrate to the community that even though there are currently members implementing another proposal, the human resources are still sufficient for the successful implementation of this proposal. It is the best way to create more trust in the community, thereby increasing the feasibility of the proposal. If doing so, the team has made sure that there is an abundant human resource to implement this proposal and affirms the team's belief and most importantly, the feasibility of the proposal to the community. I have the confidence and ability to successfully implement the proposal in practice.
In terms of technique, technology and language used when implementing the proposal. It is a collection of technologies and skills: survey, information transmission, and synthesis, Cardano blockchain, a management programming language that stores information in a decentralized way, web assessment, connectivity Cardashift, etc... It's done by 2 very knowledgeable team members, specifically with ADA, the Cardano blockchain and Catalyst. This is the basis for me to believe that the team will do a good job when implementing the technical aspect of the proposal implementation.
The team is also quite clear about the risks involved in implementing this proposal: Access to Cardashift proponents is difficult due to time constraints and is a solution to risk prevention. I add a second risk which is Ada's slippage - which will affect the budget to implement the proposal. I would like to analyze this risk more closely: We know that the digital currency market is in a downtrend phase, so the price movement in the downward direction of digital currencies takes place from time to time day. That is also the reason why Ada may depreciate when Catalyst funds are allocated to the team, then the team will face the problem of a lack of budget to implement the proposal. Therefore, my advice is for the team to review and consider the detailed budget related to Ada's slippage to make an appropriate budget request. Even if more funding is needed, the team can come up with a full plan to test.
Just now are my positive questions, comments, and advice that I would like to contribute. I hope the team can consider improving this proposal (add publicly the identities of some other members and be more detailed in the presentation of the work done. Comment on the feasibility of the proposal, I vote 4 stars.
f6_assessments.q2:
The roadmap of the proposal is presented in quite detail by the group with a total time of more than 12 months (the battle research phase is about 6 months). This is a reasonable roadmap and milestone for a proposal that takes time to implement. The work steps to be performed in each stage are very specific and in a step-by-step sequence - containing all the necessary information. However, I still have advice for the team that the team should attach the milestone roadmap to specific months of the year. If so, it will make it easier for the community to evaluate the transparency and auditability of the proposal. As a PA, I have evaluated a number of proposals and have found that not many teams can do this and this makes it easier for the community to quickly assess the transparency and auditability of the proposal. fast and accurate.
I am quite pleased to see the appearance of the job performance index (KPI). This proves that the team has carefully and specifically researched to come up with KPI criteria. The KPIs of the work associated with the proposal and the KPIs are macro - I am satisfied (Proportion of population in a certain age group; Volume of official development assistance lines). We all know the role of KPI in audit. This makes it more convenient for the community to evaluate and audit the proposal. I consider KPIs to play a certain role in demonstrating the transparency and auditability of the proposal. However, I am still looking for key metrics, the team also knows that key metrics are as important as KPIs. So my advice is to quickly add key metrics to the proposal. That would be great - the proposal would have even greater transparency and auditability.
I think the team defines "what the success of this project looks like" in a clearer, more specific way to demonstrate auditability, I credit the team for stating each of the related definitions of success. regarding the question of what success is. If the team presents a seamless presentation at the same time answering the question, without quoting another question, it will be better for the audit.
Throughout the proposal, problems and solutions were clearly articulated by the tissue group. We hope that the team will consult with me, taking note of the addition of key metrics. I agree with the auditability of the proposal. I vote 4 stars.

f6_assessments.q0:
I can see an alignment in the problem described and the challenge. Fund raising has been a major challenge especially to social enterprises, and due to that, projects within that sector tend to develop slowly if not stopped  due to insufficient funds to run activities (these projects need resources to be effective). This issue is one that falls within the critical points of the challenge and it will be a big win to Cardano if it’s considered.
Running through the provided key metrics and goals, they appear to fit into the challenge setting. The proposal’s approach appears to be scalable and functional as more African people in the ecosystem would be encouraged to apply for CLAP projects and also engaging workshops and new content with potential African proposers all about Cardashift system and how they can apply with proposals that can make a difference. However, I was expecting to see a brief explanation on what CLAP is; probably the full meaning and a brief background. CLAP projects might appear to be known by people but some people definitely wouldn’t have heard of it. That should be a matter of inclusion in future proposals. The proposer has indicated that there will be a come back to catalyst for further funding considering the fact that other resources need to be created. The proposal will be sustainable especially financial wise. 
With all that have been said, I believe that the proposal is impactful.
f6_assessments.q1:
Given information provided about the team’s relevant experience, their expertise and considering the relevant links and references attached, I am confident that they have the required skills to execute the project. The budget presented is good however, the description of the sub-items are not exhaustive. For example, there are a number of sub-items under “Research phases for 6 months” which sum up to an amount of $10,000 and I think that it shouldn’t have been so. Same appears in the other items of the budget. For a better auditing of the budget, each of the items should have had their individual costs rather than the way they are presented. Despite this vagueness, the amount requested is still sensible and reasonable to achieve the desired outcome considering that some researchers and report services will be needed. 
The roadmap is detailed; there is clarity in the timeline and deliverables. The plan does not present technical aspects that will need further explanation. 
It’s good effort that the proposer has foreseen some risk that may arise during the implementation of the project and has provided measures to mitigate it. Apart from the issues raised concerning the budget, all the other points agrees that the project is feasible.
f6_assessments.q2:
There is clarity in the roadmap’s milestones/deliverables and time horizon and hence makes auditing easy. The metrics/KPIs were wisely picked and I am confident that they are good indicators for measuring success as the chosen outputs indicate the level of interest by Africans in the cardano ecosystem. 
There is clarity in the description of the problem and I believe with the proposed solution, the problem will be tackled. It’s not clear which platform the proposer would use to share the project’s development with the community, so therefore I will recommend that the team make use of the catalyst community channels on Telegram, Discord groups and the rest so that members can track the progress of the project.
I am of the assurance that the project is auditable.

f6_assessments.q0: I like the idea for this proposal. There are a lot of proposals for this challenge setting that are implementing specific plans for the Cardashift project. The challenge that is recognized by this proposal is similar to what Cardashift is doing. The challenge is that there are lots of good projects that don't know where to go for funding. This project plans to help this by conducting research on these projects and meeting with them to discuss things such as what went well, what didn't go as planned, and how the projects could have done a better job. This will help influence the long-term plan of this project. The different companies and projects reaching out to Cardashift will know how to write a better proposal and will likely be more successful. For all of these reasons, I give this section of the proposal 5 stars. This can help bring more innovation to the Cardashift project and all of their startup projects as well.
